ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual lecture along with groupwork/discussion in small groups and among the whole class

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lots about how gardens have grown and evolved in China.

I learned about the history of Chinese parks and gardens and how various elements can be traced from multiple centuries ago (and even before that) to today. I gained a good basic grasp on important Chinese landscape/nature-related art, as well as how nature has been conceived, manipulated, and designed throughout China's history.
I learned about the history of Chinese gardens and their usage and perceptions over time.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Weaknesses: The lecture could get dry at times because people didn't want to participate which made it more awkward even for people who did want to participate. A suggestion could be encouraging everyone to get to know each other more at the start of the semester and talk in conversation with each other and not the professor. 
Strengths: Whenever we did breakout rooms, I always retained a lot of information.

The strengths were that I learned a lot and appreciated the comprehensive overview of Chinese parks and gardens and the overall conception of nature held by various Chinese people (kings, scholars, government officials, etc.) over time.

At times I felt the reading was a bit too much and did not have time to complete all of them. In these cases, I struggled with deciding on which readings to focus on first. 

I thought studying for the midterm was quite helpful for cementing a lot of what we learned. I think it would have felt a bit less overwhelming if we had received the study guide of images/quotes at the start of the semester, so we could follow along and take notes during lecture/discussion on the assigned images/quotes during the semester.

The different lenses through which we examined Chinese gardens were interesting, and the instructor was very open and engaging with each of the students. However, sometimes it was difficult to know what exactly was being evaluated in terms of graded assignments, and some of the content of the midterm seemed a bit unrelated to the material we focused on in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of slides was effective, as well as the individual meetings between the students and instructor.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if you are really interested in the material or you're going to get bored.
I would recommend to students looking for an introduction to Chinese gardens through a historical (as well as literary/artistic) lens.

The material of the course is interesting. However, the readings are often very long and the organization of the class was poor. The mid term materials were posted four days before the mid term and required students to memorize over 200 slides worth of images and quotes in the short time period. The midterm was unnecessarily difficult (may be due to an attempt to prevent cheating because it was over zoom) and not conducive to actually learning but rather quick brute memorization.  There were many projects throughout the semester that were not formal assignments that require a great deal of work outside of the course for a regular class meeting. Classes also often times went over anywhere between 10-20 minuets. Overall, the material of this course is really cool, but don't take it unless you have a great desire to learn about the topic and are prepared to dedicate more time to this course doing busy work than is necessary.
